qas.question: When did Lieutenant-Governor of New South Wales Francis Grose start suggesting Norfolk Island be closed as a penal settlement?
Why did Francis Grose think that Norfolk Island should be closed as a penal settlement?

answers.text: it was too remote and difficult for shipping and too costly to maintain

qas.question: When did the first group of people leave Norfolk Island?
By 1808, how many people remained on Norfolk Island?
Why did a small group of people remain on Norfolk Island, after others had already left?

answers.text: to slaughter stock and destroy all buildings

qas.question: When did Lieutenant-Governor of New South Wales Francis Grose start suggesting Norfolk Island be permanently opened as a penal settlement?

plausible_answers.text: it was too remote and difficult for shipping and too costly to maintain

qas.question: Why did Francis Grose think that Norfolk Island should be kept as a penal settlement?
When did the first group of people save Norfolk Island?
How many people died on Norfolk Island by 1808?

plausible_answers.text: to slaughter stock and destroy all buildings

qas.question: Why did one person remain on Norfolk Island, after others had already left?

context: As early as <a0_0><b5_0>1794<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Lieutenant-Governor of New South Wales Francis Grose suggested its closure as a penal settlement, as <a1_0><b6_0>it was too remote and difficult for shipping and too costly to maintain<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The first group of people left in <a2_0><b7_0>February 1805<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and by 1808 only about <a3_0><b8_0>200<b8_0/><a3_0/> remained, forming a small settlement until the remnants were removed in 1813. A small party remained <a4_0><b9_0>to slaughter stock and destroy all buildings<b9_0/><a4_0/>, so that there would be no inducement for anyone, especially from other European powers, to visit and lay claim to the place. From 15 February 1814 to 6 June 1825 the island was abandoned.
